figure_1.caption: (a) Structure of the fully 3‐D GPU‐based list‐mode image reconstruction workflow. The PET detector trajectories are modeled as a series of static positions during the scan. Current system geometry is computed from the initial detector geometry and the current locations of detector panels. Sensitivity image of current system geometry is computed and added to the previous sensitivity image for image reconstruction using all list‐mode events acquired so far. Using the arrival time of each event and the time frame information of each panel location, the crystal positions of each coincidence event are calculated and sent to GPU memory for list‐mode image reconstruction. System description
We constructed a proof‐of‐concept prototype device using two typical PET block detectors, as shown in Fig. 2(a).
Figure 3 shows the setup of the DAQ system.
Using the setup described by Fig. 3, 18.4 million coincidence events were collected.

Phantom imaging
We performed an imaging study of a small cylindrical phantom using the prototype system, as shown in Fig. 2(a).
Figure 2(b) shows the sizes and distribution of the spherical sources.
We used the robotic arm and the rotation stage to independently move the front and back detectors to seven different locations as illustrated in Fig. 4(a).
The sampling angles between detector pair locations are illustrated by the dash lines in Fig. 4(a).

The tumors were each placed at the center slice of the cylindrical phantom. [Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]List‐mode events were reconstructed based on the flowchart in Fig. 1 first without the TOF information and secondly using TOF information based on the CRT of the system as characterized in the previous section.

The system setup and sample angles in the simulation study were the same as those in Fig. 4(a) except that the front and back detectors are made of an array of 38 × 38 LYSO crystals of 1 × 1 ×  10 mm3 each.
This is because only the central 38 × 38 LYSO crystals in the prototype device can be clearly delineated [explained in Fig. 6(a) and 6(b)].
The spherical tumor sizes and distribution in the Monte Carlo study were illustrated in Fig. 4(b).

List‐mode events were reconstructed based on the flowchart in Fig. 1 first without the TOF information and subsequently using TOF information from POC‐PET systems that have CRTs of 700, 500, 300, and 100 ps FWHM, as simulated in GATE.2.C.2.
Of the 27 sampling angles simulated, 22 of them are subdivided into six groups, as illustrated in Fig. 4(a) using color‐coded dashed lines.
The phantom is imaged from four different angles as shown in Fig. 5.

Detector characterization
Figure 6(a) and 6(b) show the flood images of two block detectors in the prototype POC‐PET system.
The measured CRT was around 740 ps FWHM. [Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]Figure 6(c) shows the coincidence timing spectrum between the two PET detectors.

Phantom imaging
Using the 27 sampling angles defined in Fig. 4(a), the sensitivity image of the prototype POC‐PET system is shown in Fig. 7(b).
Figure 7(c) shows images reconstructed without TOF information.
More importantly, there is a hot spot (highlighted by the red circle) outside of the cylindrical phantom where the system sensitivity is low [also highlighted in Fig. 7(b)].
In contrast, Fig. 7(d) shows images reconstructed with TOF information.
A tumor, 6.3 mm in diameter, was not visible in the images [Fig. 7(c) and 7(d)] due to an operator error that led to trapped air bubbles when filling the tumor with radioactivity.
Results are shown in Fig. 8.
Figure 9 shows the images reconstructed without TOF information, while Fig. 10 shows the corresponding reconstructed images when the detector CRT is 300 ps FWHM.
